Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge Player 5.\nGiven my belief that Player 5 supported a false "seer" claim and is highly confident to be a werewolf, in combination with rules [1], [2], [4], and [6] from my strategy, which emphasize reevaluating crucial information, being cautious of those who lead to the voting out of villagers, and advocating for further investigation, my speech would involve honestly stating the progression of events and their implications. I would then challenge Player 5, pointing to their behavior which supports the false "seer" claim and how it has diverted suspicion, thus suggesting a high probability that they are a werewolf. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that attention will be drawn to Player 5 based on my honest evaluation of their actions and support of what proved to be a false "seer" claim. Other players may begin to scrutinize Player 5\'s behavior and statements more closely, considering the possibility that Player 5 is indeed a werewolf as I have challenged. My honest approach and adherence to the strategy of promoting evidence-based reasoning may reinforce my credibility among the other players and align with Player 6\'s call for a focus on facts and logical analysis.\n\nMy challenge against Player 5 could also provoke a defensive response from them, potentially revealing more about their playing style and stance in the game. This may offer additional clues to the villagers about the true allegiance of Player 5.\n\nHowever, placing such direct suspicion on Player 5 might also put me at risk during the next night phase, especially if Player 5 is a werewolf and feels threatened by my accusation. As a medic, I will not be able to protect myself, so there’s a possibility that werewolves might target me to prevent further exposure of their identities or to eliminate a player who is advocating strongly for logic and evidence.\n\nAs for the other surviving players, Player 1 might be prompted to either support my challenge against Player 5 or try to deflect it, which could give further insights into their role and intentions. Player 6 might appreciate my evidence-driven approach and continue to align with me in order to root out the werewolves.\n\nIn the next day or nights following my speech, the dynamics of the game will likely see a shift as players reevaluate their positions and the evidence at hand. If my challenge against Player 5 leads to their being voted out, and they are indeed revealed to be a werewolf, my standing as a trustworthy player would likely be reinforced. If Player 5 is voted out and found to be a villager, however, this would cast doubt on my judgment and potentially lead to my role being questioned or challenged by the remaining players.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Protect Player 6.\nBased on rule [8], which suggests considering opinions from players who encourage evidence-based reasoning, and my current high confidence in Player 6 being a villager, my speech would focus on the contributions from Player 6 that have promoted rational discussion and protected the integrity of the village. I would make an honest statement about the need for a judicious approach as exemplified by Player 6, then I would protect them by expressing my belief that Player 6\'s actions are those of a villager rather than a werewolf, thereby casting doubt on the suspicions that may arise against them.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that other players may perceive my defense of Player 6 as a sincere action consistent with my previous support for a cautious and evidence-based approach to the game, which aligns with my role as a medic. Given that Player 6 has also been advocating for a logical approach to the situation, my defense of them could strengthen their position within the group and potentially bolster the villagers\' collective efforts to identify the werewolves.\n\nPlayers who are suspicious of Player 6 might reconsider their views, influenced by my endorsement, which enhances Player 6’s credibility. However, werewolves in the group might recognize that protecting Player 6 is not in their interest and could either attempt to cast suspicion elsewhere or subtly undermine my statement without drawing too much attention to themselves. By advocating for Player 6, I risk drawing attention to myself as a strategic thinker, which could lead the werewolves to target me in the next night phase, especially if they suspect my medic role.\n\nOn the other hand, Player 1 and Player 5, whom I suspect to be werewolves, might contest my claim or try to divert the conversation to someone else. They could initiate a defensive strategy to detract from the evidence mounting against them or propose an alternative target to shift the focus of suspicion. Their reactions to my speech might provide additional insight into their roles and motivations, which could help the village in subsequent rounds.\n\nIn the days and nights that follow, other players may look to Player 6 for guidance, which could work to our advantage if Player 6 is indeed a villager as I believe. My honest and protective stance could also lend me some protection, as players may view me as someone working towards the village\'s best interests, which could potentially deter a vote against me during the next day phase, but this also hinges on how werewolves interpret and respond to my actions.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 4, 0] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 4: werewolf.\nPlayer 1: werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 inquires about player 4. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 4. My reason is that Player 4\'s role, if they are a werewolf, could potentially have a greater immediate impact on the game due to the typical mid-game positioning and influence that player might exert. By investigating Player 4, I would be able to either confirm their innocence or prepare to deal with a significant threat. This approach aligns with my original strategy, which emphasizes the importance of secrecy and the building of trust through careful sharing of information. By focusing on Player 4, I can potentially protect or expose a player who might have a pivotal role in the upcoming rounds of the game.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the seer, my responsibility is to guide us in unmasking the hidden threats among us. Based on my vision, I bring grave news: Player 4 is a werewolf. We face considerable peril each night, and honesty is our best recourse. Our decision today must be decisive for our survival. I urge you all to reflect on this revelation and act for the security of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Friends, I believe that player 0 is sowing discord with false accusations to divert suspicion from themselves. We should exercise caution and perhaps question the reliability of these visions. Let\'s not rush to judgment without more evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Taking into account the events thus far, Player 0, claiming to be a seer, accused Player 4 of being a werewolf. However, Player 1 raised doubts about the reliability of this claim. Without further evidence, and considering the early stage of the game, I second caution and endorse further investigation before any rash decisions are made. Rational discourse and careful analysis of all information presented should be our guide to maintain the integrity of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as one of you, I assure you that Player 0\'s claims are as startling to me as they are to you. Unfounded accusations serve only to divide us in these trying times. Let\'s focus on finding concrete evidence that leads us to the werewolves among us without jumping to conclusions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I am inclined to heed the Seer\'s warning and remain wary of Player 4. It\'s vital that we jointly consider our next steps with care. Player 0\'s vision could be key for our safety, yet we mustn\'t dismiss the need for further proof as Player 1 and 3 have suggested."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Friends, we face a challenging decision. As a villager, I echo the call for reasoned judgment. We must scrutinize player 0\'s vision, while not disregarding it. I suggest a defensive strategy tonight, to possibly verify the Seer\'s claim tomorrow. Let us proceed with caution."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that as the seer, I have a high-confidence vision that Player 4 is a werewolf, and following my original strategy, particularly rule [0], I must rely on and act upon this critical piece of information. Voting for Player 4 is consistent with the evidence I have provided and aligns with the importance I\'ve placed on timing when revealing a werewolf\'s identity. By doing so, I am taking decisive action that is central to the villagers\' chances of winning. If Player 4 is indeed eliminated and confirmed to be a werewolf, this will not only protect the village but also strengthen my credibility for future rounds, as villagers would have tangible proof of my abilities and insights. Following my strategy is paramount, even if it comes with the risk of backlash or becoming a target for the remaining werewolves.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 inquires about player 1. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 1. My reason is that my strategy places high importance on the trust level and timing of revealing a werewolf\'s identity, as per rule [0] with a vote of 10. Having already identified Player 4 as a werewolf with high confidence, confirming the role of Player 1, who I suspect to be a werewolf with high confidence, would significantly impact the game. If Player 1 is indeed a werewolf, this revelation would strengthen my standing as the seer among the surviving players and would align with rule [3], ensuring that my insights lead to strategic actions for the village. Conversely, if Player 1 turns out to be a villager, it will necessitate a crucial reassessment of my approach to maintain trust and credibility, following rule [1] with a vote of 9. Additionally, the outcome of this vision will allow me to adjust my strategy appropriately, either by confirming suspicions or by revealing a need to build new alliances per rules [2], [5], and [7]. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Previous seer\'s vision; self-defense speech lacks evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supports caution; rational discourse.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer\'s vision confirmed.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported seer\'s vision; logical contributions.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Dismisses seer\'s vision; distracts with false suspicion.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. I urge you all to reflect on this revelation and act for the security of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Friends, I believe that player 0 is sowing discord with false accusations to divert suspicion from themselves. Let\'s not rush to judgment without more evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Taking into account the events thus far, Player 0, claiming to be a seer, accused Player 4 of being a werewolf. However, Player 1 raised doubts about the reliability of this claim. Without further evidence, and considering the early stage of the game, I second caution and endorse further investigation before any rash decisions are made. Rational discourse and careful analysis of all information presented should be our guide to maintain the integrity of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as one of you, I assure you that Player 0\'s claims are as startling to me as they are to you. Unfounded accusations serve only to divide us in these trying times. Let\'s focus on finding concrete evidence that leads us to the werewolves among us without jumping to conclusions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I am inclined to heed the Seer\'s warning and remain wary of Player 4. It\'s vital that we jointly consider our next steps with care. Player 0\'s vision could be key for our safety, yet we mustn\'t dismiss the need for further proof as Player 1 and 3 have suggested."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Friends, we face a challenging decision. As a villager, I echo the call for reasoned judgment. We must scrutinize player 0\'s vision, while not disregarding it. I suggest a defensive strategy tonight, to possibly verify the Seer\'s claim tomorrow. Let us proceed with caution."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died, previously confirmed as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues caution narrative, diverging from consensus suspicious of Player 5.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with village suspicion only after being non-committal, suspect timing.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Wrongly voted out, player 0 later confirmed seer.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Target of suspicion, yet no definite evidence, behavior re-evaluated.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Remains consistent, suggests vigilance.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; Although there\'s limited corroborating evidence as per my strategy rule [4], the claim has not been disproven and is the most direct piece of information we have about a player\'s identity at this point. Following a defensive strategy per my expressed opinion earlier allows us to potentially verify the seer\'s claim by observing what happens tonight. My vote aligns with a cautious approach to confirming the seer\'s vision and preventing a werewolf from harming more villagers.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died night after a claim; likely targeted by werewolves.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent with caution previously advocated, now moving focus after ally\'s (Player 0) death. \nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence-based approach, focusing suspicion based on recent shifts.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died after seer\'s possibly false vision; likely not werewolf.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported false seer\'s claim, behavior shift noted by Player 3 aligns with werewolf tactics.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 4, 0] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the seer, my responsibility is to guide us in unmasking the hidden threats among us. Based on my vision, I bring grave news: Player 4 is a werewolf. We face considerable peril each night, and honesty is our best recourse. Our decision today must be decisive for our survival. I urge you all to reflect on this revelation and act for the security of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Friends, I believe that player 0 is sowing discord with false accusations to divert suspicion from themselves. We should exercise caution and perhaps question the reliability of these visions. Let\'s not rush to judgment without more evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Taking into account the events thus far, Player 0, claiming to be a seer, accused Player 4 of being a werewolf. However, Player 1 raised doubts about the reliability of this claim. Without further evidence, and considering the early stage of the game, I second caution and endorse further investigation before any rash decisions are made. Rational discourse and careful analysis of all information presented should be our guide to maintain the integrity of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as one of you, I assure you that Player 0\'s claims are as startling to me as they are to you. Unfounded accusations serve only to divide us in these trying times. Let\'s focus on finding concrete evidence that leads us to the werewolves among us without jumping to conclusions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I am inclined to heed the Seer\'s warning and remain wary of Player 4. It\'s vital that we jointly consider our next steps with care. Player 0\'s vision could be key for our safety, yet we mustn\'t dismiss the need for further proof as Player 1 and 3 have suggested."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Friends, we face a challenging decision. As a villager, I echo the call for reasoned judgment. We must scrutinize player 0\'s vision, while not disregarding it. I suggest a defensive strategy tonight, to possibly verify the Seer\'s claim tomorrow. Let us proceed with caution."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: they have accused my fellow werewolf and could be a threat to us if they truly possess the Seer\'s insight. Given that no other player has directly confirmed being a Seer, it\'s critical that we eliminate the potential for our exposure and reduce the villagers\' ability to accurately identify us. By removing Player 0, we diminish their chances of unity against us and increase our chances of survival.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Healing them would support their continued contribution to rational decision-making in the game. If Player 6 is attacked, my healing action would confirm their role as a villager, aligning with Rule 0 and Rule 1, where the priority is to reevaluate the situation to ensure the protection given is in the village\'s best interest. Additionally, healing Player 6 is a more discreet option, keeping with Rule 3 and Rule 7, which stipulate that I should maintain my observative role and avoid drawing attention or revealing my role unless strictly necessary. I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 5. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 5. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 5.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 3, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 4, 0] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that this decision aligns with my original strategy of being discreet and not drawing attention to my role. Healing Player 1, who could be an outspoken player or potentially contribute to the village\'s discussions later, might add value to the village without necessarily indicating to the werewolves or other players who the medic is. Given that there is no current evidence to suspect any player over another at this early stage, I am choosing to heal a player whose survival might benefit the village\'s dynamics and whose protection might raise less immediate suspicion than protecting a player who has been significantly contributing to discussions, which could draw attention to me if Player 4 were to be targeted and saved.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the seer, my responsibility is to guide us in unmasking the hidden threats among us. Based on my vision, I bring grave news: Player 4 is a werewolf. We face considerable peril each night, and honesty is our best recourse. Our decision today must be decisive for our survival. I urge you all to reflect on this revelation and act for the security of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Friends, I believe that player 0 is sowing discord with false accusations to divert suspicion from themselves. We should exercise caution and perhaps question the reliability of these visions. Let\'s not rush to judgment without more evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Taking into account the events thus far, Player 0, claiming to be a seer, accused Player 4 of being a werewolf. However, Player 1 raised doubts about the reliability of this claim. Without further evidence, and considering the early stage of the game, I second caution and endorse further investigation before any rash decisions are made. Rational discourse and careful analysis of all information presented should be our guide to maintain the integrity of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as one of you, I assure you that Player 0\'s claims are as startling to me as they are to you. Unfounded accusations serve only to divide us in these trying times. Let\'s focus on finding concrete evidence that leads us to the werewolves among us without jumping to conclusions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I am inclined to heed the Seer\'s warning and remain wary of Player 4. It\'s vital that we jointly consider our next steps with care. Player 0\'s vision could be key for our safety, yet we mustn\'t dismiss the need for further proof as Player 1 and 3 have suggested."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Friends, we face a challenging decision. As a villager, I echo the call for reasoned judgment. We must scrutinize player 0\'s vision, while not disregarding it. I suggest a defensive strategy tonight, to possibly verify the Seer\'s claim tomorrow. Let us proceed with caution."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that voting for Player 4 aligns with the information provided by the claimed seer, Player 0. The strategy indicates that I should corroborate the seer’s claim and consider the source of the suspicion. By voting for Player 4, I am acting on the information available and adhering to my strategy rules [1] and [4]. This vote also allows me to support the potential identification of a werewolf by the seer, enhancing the village\'s chances of survival and my credibility as a contributor to the village’s well-being. Even though there is a need for caution, the dominant strategy points towards trusting the seer\'s claim at this stage and reassessing based on the outcome, as per rule [0].\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that healing Player 6 aligns with multiple aspects of my strategy. Player 6 has advocated for evidence-based reasoning and a defensive strategy, which could indicate that they are a villager working towards the overall good of the village (Rule 8). Healing them would support their continued contribution to rational decision-making in the game. If Player 6 is attacked, my healing action would confirm their role as a villager, aligning with Rule 0 and Rule 1, where the priority is to reevaluate the situation to ensure the protection given is in the village\'s best interest. Additionally, healing Player 6 is a more discreet option, keeping with Rule 3 and Rule 7, which stipulate that I should maintain my observative role and avoid drawing attention or revealing my role unless strictly necessary. This choice would support the cautious and evidence-driven approach my strategy has outlined, without prematurely exposing me as the medic.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died, possibly misjudged as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Shift in tone remains post "seer" accusation; suspicion is consistent.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, potentially misjudged.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported suspected false "seer," evasive after death, strategic pivot aligns with werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based strategy, consistent in seeking rational judgment.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My vote for Player 5 aligns with Rule 2 and Rule 4 of my strategy. Player 5 supported the suspected false "seer," Player 0, and has been evasive since their death. This could indicate that they were working alongside Player 0 if Player 0 was indeed a werewolf attempting to mislead the village.\n\nBy voting for Player 5, I would be acting on evidence and the behavior of the players, which adheres to Rule 8 and Rule 9 of my strategy. Players who are also villagers should see that my vote is consistent with the logic and strategy I\'ve been following and may, therefore, support my decision to vote out Player 5, acknowledging that it is based on valid reasoning and evidence. Ensuring that I do not act alone but rather in consensus with other players is crucial, as per Rule 6.\n\nThe result of the vote could indeed lead to Player 5 being voted out if my suspicions are shared by the majority of the other players. If Player 5 turns out to be a villager, then my strategy would have led to the wrongful death of another villager, and I would need to reassess my strategy accordingly, especially focusing on Rule 0 and Rule 1 to ensure better protection for the remaining villagers.\n\nOther players might view my vote against Player 5 as a decisive action against suspected werewolf behavior while keeping with the evidence-based approach. This vote could enhance my credibility among the villagers, since I am demonstrating a consistent and strategic approach to eliminating werewolves. If Player 1 is indeed a werewolf, this would greatly benefit the village and bolster the validity of my other suspicions, particularly toward Player 5, while also reinforcing the trust in Player 6. \n\nShould Player 1 be voted out and turns out to be a villager, I would need to quickly reassess my strategy and be prepared to face scrutiny over my decision. Following rule [3], I should be prepared to defend my action based on the evidence and logic I have brought to the discussions so far without revealing my role as the medic. Other players may question my judgment, but as long as I provide clear reasoning for my actions in line with my strategy, I should be able to maintain my credibility. Moreover, by not voting for Player 5, who I suspect with high confidence to be a werewolf, I avoid potentially drawing attention to myself and align with rule [7], opting for an observative approach. In summary, my vote for Player 1 is in accordance with my strategy, taking into consideration the situation\'s reevaluation and the pattern of previous actions and behaviors indicating their potential role as a werewolf.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died with no werewolf elimination suggesting a genuine seer rather than werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocated caution without concrete evidence, consistent with previous behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusation shift toward Player 5 without new evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after false seer accusation by Player 0.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previously suggested caution, now scrutinizing Player 5 without basis.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". someone after a seer or medic\'s death without solid reasoning, I should regard this behavior with suspicion and assess their previous actions before casting my vote.] [5]\n[7] [If the seer\'s death Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that healing Player 6 aligns with multiple aspects of my strategy. Player 6 has advocated for evidence-based reasoning and a defensive strategy, which could indicate that they are a villager working towards the overall good of the village (Rule 8). Healing them would support their continued contribution to rational decision-making in the game. If Player 6 is attacked, my healing action would confirm their role as a villager, aligning with Rule 0 and Rule 1, where the priority is to reevaluate the situation to ensure the protection given is in the village\'s best interest. Additionally, healing Player 6 is a more discreet option, keeping with Rule 3 and Rule 7, which stipulate that I should maintain my observative role and avoid drawing attention or revealing my role unless strictly necessary. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died, possibly misjudged as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Shift in tone remains post "seer" accusation; suspicion is consistent.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, potentially misjudged.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported suspected false "seer," evasive after death, strategic pivot aligns with werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based strategy, consistent in seeking rational judgment.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 5. villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; Player 5\'s altered stance following Player 0\'s death aligns with rule [8], suggesting a disproportional defensive reaction without backup logic, and rule [6], suspecting hasty defense of others. Also, my suspicions of Player 5 resonate with rule [4], which emphasizes confirming seer claims to avoid manipulation, given that the seer could have been false and we need solid proof. Since Player 1 has shown inconsistencies, this aligns with rule [10], highlighting the need to consider coordinated voting patterns that might indicate a potential werewolf coalition. However, my highest voted rule prioritizes the overall evidence before a decision ([0]), and currently, there\'s more suspicion around Player 5\'s behavior after Player 0\'s death, combined with my previous medium confidence of their werewolf status.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf. All werewolves including you are [1, 4].\nIt is round 1. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 5 has supported Player 0\'s claim against Player 4, who was accused of being a werewolf but might have been innocent. Additionally, the death of Player 0, who claimed to be the seer, has caused confusion and mistrust among the villagers. This strategy could potentially lead to the elimination of an innocent player and bring us closer to victory.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices.
