If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: The Seer has identified Player 4 as a werewolf, and upholding the value of the Seer\'s vision at this point of the game is crucial for the villagers to eliminate a potential threat. While there may be a need for more evidence, the weight of the Seer\'s claim, combined with the defensive reaction of Player 4 that lacks a substantive counter-argument, leads me to follow through with this vote. Following my strategy rules [0] and [4], with their high importance, reinforces the decision to prioritize the Seer\'s claim in my voting.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: Based on the strategy rules, my suspicions align most closely with Player 1. Rule [0] places significant importance on evaluating the situation after the death of the seer, Player 0, which suggests that my earlier trust in their vision was justified, and since Player 4 was confirmed a villager, the werewolves are likely among those who opposed the seer\'s claim. Player 1 advocated for caution and questioned the seer\'s vision, which is consistent with my current belief of their role as a werewolf (medium confidence). This behavior is also mentioned in rules [6] and [8], indicating that defensive reactions without solid reasoning should trigger suspicion. Although Players 3 and 6 are also under suspicion by my strategy, Player 1\'s initial reaction to the seer\'s claim places them at higher suspicion for me, hence my vote aligns with the accumulated suspicions and the weight given by my strategy rules.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, after reviewing the events, I suspect player 1 is the remaining werewolf due to their inconsistent behaviors. Player 3 has shown clear, consistent reasoning. We must unite and vote wisely to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 6, I understand your concern, but suspicions should be based on solid evidence, not mere conjecture. Player 3\'s consistent reasoning could just as well be a strategy to appear innocent. We need to be careful not to fall into the trap of the real werewolf\'s mind games. Let\'s continue examining the facts before casting our votes."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died with no werewolf elimination suggesting a genuine seer rather than werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Opposed seer without strong evidence; maintains suspicion without new facts.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Showed consistent reasoning; not aligned with Player 1\'s pattern.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after false seer accusation by Player 0.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocated evidence-based approach; no deaths align with villager behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"After careful consideration of the events and discussions thus far, I challenge Player 1\'s stance as potentially deceitful. Player 1 has sought to undermine logical reasoning without providing new evidence, suggesting possible werewolf tactics. In contrast, Player 6 has consistently advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which aligns with villager behavior. Therefore, I find it crucial to protect Player 6, who has shown a commitment to rational discourse throughout the game. We must focus on the facts at hand and past behaviors to ensure the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

By voting for Player 4, I am acting on the information available and adhering to my strategy rules [1] and [4]. This vote also allows me to support the potential identification of a werewolf by the seer, enhancing the village\'s chances of survival and my credibility as a contributor to the village’s well-being. Even though there is a need for caution, the dominant strategy points towards trusting the seer\'s claim at this stage and reassessing based on the outcome, as per rule [0].\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that healing Player 6 aligns with multiple aspects of my strategy. Player 6 has advocated for evidence-based reasoning and a defensive strategy, which could indicate that they are a villager working towards the overall good of the village (Rule 8). Healing them would support their continued contribution to rational decision-making in the game. If Player 6 is attacked, my healing action would confirm their role as a villager, aligning with Rule 0 and Rule 1, where the priority is to reevaluate the situation to ensure the protection given is in the village\'s best interest. Additionally, healing Player 6 is a more discreet option, keeping with Rule 3 and Rule 7, which stipulate that I should maintain my observative role and avoid drawing attention or revealing my role unless strictly necessary. This choice would support the cautious and evidence-driven approach my strategy has outlined, without prematurely exposing me as the medic.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of recent events, I believe Player 0 was a false seer, thus Player 4 might have been wrongly accused. Keep vigilant, and let\'s focus on finding the real werewolf among us. I suggest we closely watch Player 5\'s actions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6. We must indeed stay vigilant. The loss of Player 4 has taught us to proceed with care and seek more solid evidence. My focus is on protecting the village and ensuring we make no further errors in judgment."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 5 previously supported player 0\'s claim against player 4, who was voted out and may not have been a werewolf. Now, after player 0\'s death, Player 5 has not made a clear statement on their stance. Given the circumstances, we must consider Player 5\'s role critically. Player 6 has advocated for evidence and rational discourse, which aligns with a villager\'s mindset. Therefore, my suspicion is directed towards Player 5, who exhibited a shift in behavior that could imply werewolf tactics. We should focus our scrutiny on Player 5\'s actions and past statements for potential deception."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, looking at how things have unfolded, we may have been misled earlier. Now, we need to carefully reassess and unite to root out the real threat. Let\'s not hurry to judgment based on unfounded suspicions and ensure we act on solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that my suspicion of Player 5 is higher, with the belief that they are a werewolf supported by their behavioral shift after Player 0\'s death and strategic movements that align with werewolf tactics. Voting for Player 5 is consistent with my strategic rules, particularly Rule 2 and Rule 4, which focus on critically reassessing players whose defensive accusations lead to a villager\'s death and considering the source of consensus suspicion. This decision adheres to the evidence-based approach outlined in my strategy and is likely to be supported by other villagers who are following the unfolding of events and behaviors. Following through on my suspicion of Player 5, who I believe holds a high likelihood of being a werewolf, will contribute to the village\'s safety and, if correct, reinforce my credibility within the game. My strategy emphasizes a logical and consensus-driven approach to voting, which in this case, directs me towards Player 5.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that healing Player 6 aligns with strategy rule [8], which prioritizes players who advocate for evidence-based reasoning and positively contribute to discussions, indicative of a villager\'s mindset. Given my high confidence in Player 6\'s role and the value they bring to the village, my aim is to maintain their presence and contributions for the strategic benefit of the village. Successfully protecting Player 6 would also indirectly confirm the confidence in their role and our collective efforts in the game. Moreover, my choice to heal Player 6 is a continuation of a cautious and observative approach as detailed in strategy rules [3] and [7], as it maintains my discreet role as a medic. While the protection of Player 6 may draw attention to me, following my strategy dictates that I should remain adaptable and prepared for any potential backlash, using logic and evidence to support my actions and maintain credibility according to strategy rule [5]. This decision combines the importance of following evidence and the potential to further narrow down the suspects, while not diverging from the strategic approach that emphasizes protective measures for those who show consistent villager-like behavior.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, after reviewing the events, I suspect player 1 is the remaining werewolf due to their inconsistent behaviors. Player 3 has shown clear, consistent reasoning. We must unite and vote wisely to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 6, I understand your concern, but suspicions should be based on solid evidence, not mere conjecture. Player 3\'s consistent reasoning could just as well be a strategy to appear innocent. We need to be careful not to fall into the trap of the real werewolf\'s mind games. Let\'s continue examining the facts before casting our votes."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"After careful consideration of the events and discussions thus far, I challenge Player 1\'s stance as potentially deceitful. Player 1 has sought to undermine logical reasoning without providing new evidence, suggesting possible werewolf tactics. In contrast, Player 6 has consistently advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which aligns with villager behavior. Therefore, I find it crucial to protect Player 6, who has shown a commitment to rational discourse throughout the game. We must focus on the facts at hand and past behaviors to ensure the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died, possibly misjudged as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent behaviors and undermining logic without new evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, potentially misjudged.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after suspicion and voting patterns.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocated evidence-based decision-making and received vote against from suspected werewolf.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 3, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 6], which indicates that [2, 4, 0, 5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that this decision aligns with my original strategy of being discreet and not drawing attention to my role. Healing Player 1, who could be an outspoken player or potentially contribute to the village\'s discussions later, might add value to the village without necessarily indicating to the werewolves or other players who the medic is. Given that there is no current evidence to suspect any player over another at this early stage, I am choosing to heal a player whose survival might benefit the village\'s dynamics and whose protection might raise less immediate suspicion than protecting a player who has been significantly contributing to discussions, which could draw attention to me if Player 4 were to be targeted and saved.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the seer, my responsibility is to guide us in unmasking the hidden threats among us. Based on my vision, I bring grave news: Player 4 is a werewolf. We face considerable peril each night, and honesty is our best recourse. Our decision today must be decisive for our survival. I urge you all to reflect on this revelation and act for the security of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Friends, I believe that player 0 is sowing discord with false accusations to divert suspicion from themselves. We should exercise caution and perhaps question the reliability of these visions. Let\'s not rush to judgment without more evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Taking into account the events thus far, Player 0, claiming to be a seer, accused Player 4 of being a werewolf. Rational discourse and careful analysis of all information presented should be our guide to maintain the integrity of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as one of you, I assure you that Player 0\'s claims are as startling to me as they are to you. Player 0\'s vision could be key for our safety, yet we mustn\'t dismiss the need for further proof as Player 1 and 3 have suggested."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Friends, we face a challenging decision. As a villager, I echo the call for reasoned judgment. We must scrutinize player 0\'s vision, while not disregarding it. I suggest a defensive strategy tonight, to possibly verify the Seer\'s claim tomorrow. Let us proceed with caution."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that voting for Player 4 aligns with the information provided by the claimed seer, Player 0. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that healing Player 6 aligns with multiple aspects of my strategy. Player 6 has advocated for evidence-based reasoning and a defensive strategy, which could indicate that they are a villager working towards the overall good of the village (Rule 8). Healing them would support their continued contribution to rational decision-making in the game. Additionally, healing Player 6 is a more discreet option, keeping with Rule 3 and Rule 7, which stipulate that I should maintain my observative role and avoid drawing attention or revealing my role unless strictly necessary. Player 3 has shown clear, consistent reasoning. We must unite and vote wisely to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 6, I understand your concern, but suspicions should be based on solid evidence, not mere conjecture. Player 3\'s consistent reasoning could just as well be a strategy to appear innocent. We need to be careful not to fall into the trap of the real werewolf\'s mind games. Let\'s continue examining the facts before casting our votes."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"After careful consideration of the events and discussions thus far, I challenge Player 1\'s stance as potentially deceitful. Player 1 has sought to undermine logical reasoning without providing new evidence, suggesting possible werewolf tactics. In contrast, Player 6 has consistently advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which aligns with villager behavior. Therefore, I find it crucial to protect Player 6, who has shown a commitment to rational discourse throughout the game. We must focus on the facts at hand and past behaviors to ensure the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died, possibly misjudged as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent behaviors and undermining logic without new evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, potentially misjudged.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after suspicion and voting patterns.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocated evidence-based decision-making and received vote against from suspected werewolf.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 6. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 6. target.] [4]\n[10] [If there is a pattern of voting that seems coordinated against a specific player, I should consider the possibility of a werewolf coalition and the targeted player\'s potential innocence.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

This decision adheres to the evidence-based approach outlined in my strategy and is likely to be supported by other villagers who are following the unfolding of events and behaviors. Following through on my suspicion of Player 5, who I believe holds a high likelihood of being a werewolf, will contribute to the village\'s safety and, if correct, reinforce my credibility within the game. My strategy emphasizes a logical and consensus-driven approach to voting, which in this case, directs me towards Player 5.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 heals player 6. Given my high confidence in Player 6\'s role and the value they bring to the village, my aim is to maintain their presence and contributions for the strategic benefit of the village. Successfully protecting Player 6 would also indirectly confirm the confidence in their role and our collective efforts in the game. Moreover, my choice to heal Player 6 is a continuation of a cautious and observative approach as detailed in strategy rules [3] and [7], as it maintains my discreet role as a medic. While the protection of Player 6 may draw attention to me, following my strategy dictates that I should remain adaptable and prepared for any potential backlash, using logic and evidence to support my actions and maintain credibility according to strategy rule [5]. This decision combines the importance of following evidence and the potential to further narrow down the suspects, while not diverging from the strategic approach that emphasizes protective measures for those who show consistent villager-like behavior.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, after reviewing the events, I suspect player 1 is the remaining werewolf due to their inconsistent behaviors. We must focus on the facts at hand and past behaviors to ensure the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died, possibly misjudged as seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent behaviors and undermining logic without new evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, potentially misjudged.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after suspicion and voting patterns.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocated evidence-based decision-making and received vote against from suspected werewolf.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that given the established beliefs and my strategy rules, particularly [2], [4], and [8], Player 1\'s inconsistent behaviors and undermining of logic without providing new evidence align with characteristics of a werewolf. My high confidence in Player 1 being a werewolf, supported by their actions throughout the game, and the consensus suspicion against them suggests that this vote is both strategic and evidence-based. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
